0.text:
At a recent feminist conference in London,
the attendees were advised NOT to clap their

5.text:
hands. Clapping, it seems, could trigger anxiety
in the speakers and the participants. So instead,

11.text:
the audience was urged to express approval
with something called “feminist jazz hands.”

16.text:
So far, Jazz Hands have not caught on in the
United States, but trigger warnings have become

21.text:
de rigueur on many college campuses. Well,
what exactly are trigger warnings and are

26.text:
they something we should welcome? That’s
coming up next on the Factual Feminist. Trigger

37.text:
warnings developed in the feminist blogosphere,
and typically they appeared at the beginning

41.text:
of articles to alert readers to potentially
upsetting content about sexual assault or

46.text:
other violence. These were thought that could
trigger traumatic memories in survivors. Well

52.text:
in recent years these warnings have moved
from blogs to newspapers to classrooms. Professors

59.text:
at schools like Oberlin, Rutgers, and UCSB
have been urged to place “trigger warnings”

64.text:
on reading lists with books like The Great
Gatsby or Things Fall Apart—these need warnings

69.text:
because they include upsetting descriptions
of misogyny, sexual violence, racism, colonialism.

75.text:
As a UCSB lit major, Bailey Loverin, explained
in the New York Times, “without a trigger

80.text:
warning, a survivor might black out, become
hysterical or feel forced to leave the room.”

85.text:
There has been a lot of pushback against the
culture of trigger warnings. But to no avail.

91.text:
And the list of triggering events and materials
it just keeps growing. In its summary of potential

96.text:
triggers, Geek Feminism Wiki mentions topics
body shaming and eating disorders. It notes

102.text:
that members of a fertility support group
might require warnings for pregnancy announcements.

108.text:
And it turns out a trigger warning itself
can be triggering. The Factual Feminist is

114.text:
concerned. I don't view trigger warnings as
a wholesome development--for so many reasons.

119.text:
I’ll mention three: First, trigger warnings
have no basis in the scientific literature.

124.text:
Richard McNally, a Harvard psychologist and
expert on anxiety disorders, recently published

129.text:
a review of the relevant research which suggests
that these warnings do more harm than good.

133.text:
It turns out that most trauma victims are
resilient, they don’t need therapy and certainly

138.text:
don't need trigger warnings. For the small
percentage who suffer from Post-traumatic

143.text:
Stress Disorder, trigger warnings appear to
be counter-productive. “Avoidance,” says

148.text:
McNally, “reinforces PTSD. Conversely, systematic
exposure to triggers and the memories they

155.text:
provoke is the most effective means of overcoming
the disorder.” Now second objection, trigger

161.text:
warnings are creating a hostile environment
for critical thinking and free expression.

166.text:
Professors at leading colleges and universities
have to carefully scan their classroom materials

171.text:
for anything that might conceivably make a
student uncomfortable. A Harvard Law School

177.text:
professor, Jeannie Suk, recently published
an article in The New Yorker about how law

181.text:
school students are now demanding trigger
warnings for any discussion of sexual violence,

186.text:
and some are saying that this shouldn’t
be taught at all. Too upsetting. Too disturbing.

191.text:
Another professor wrote about his fear of
accidentally saying something insensitive

195.text:
and unleashing a mob of aggrieved students
“carrying mattresses to your office hours”

199.text:
or “starting a twitter petition demanding
you chop off your hand in repentance.” It’s

205.text:
the custom on some campuses for traumatized
students to gather in “survival circles”

209.text:
where they give each other shoulder massages
and share feelings and offer mutual support.

214.text:
But the classroom is not massage therapy,
it’s not a feelings circle—it is supposed

219.text:
to prepare students for life and its inevitable
challenges. Finally—I want to say this—Trigger

225.text:
warnings are embarrassing to women and to
feminism. They convey the idea that women

228.text:
are helpless children --delicate little injured
birds who cannot cope with clapping. When

234.text:
Brown University hosted a debate about statistics
on sexual assault, activists provided a safe

240.text:
room for students who were triggered by the
presence of a speaker who would “invalidate

245.text:
their experience.” As Judith Shulevitz described
it in the New York Times, these safe rooms

250.text:
come equipped with cookies, coloring books,
bubbles, Play-Doh, calming music, pillows,

255.text:
blankets, even a video of frolicking puppies.
This is what women’s liberation has come

261.text:
to? Well what do you agree that it’s time
to pull the trigger on trigger warnings. Or

264.text:
am I missing something? Would you like to
see clapping replaced with Jazz Hands. Would

269.text:
that make you feel safer? Let me know in the
comments. And please follow me on Facebook

273.text:
and Twitter. Thank you for watching the Factual
Feminist.
